content.description: Matt Maddaloni and John Millar put up this twelve-pitch aid route over eight days on the formation Carag-Dur. Carag-Dur, although it is among the smaller walls in the valley, easily rivals the chief. Good Luck.
content.location: See Carag-dur area description and beta photo
content.protection: Any party attempting this route should remember to bring at least 40 heads and 25 bird beaks.

content.description:
A fun aid route up the left side of the wall which follows good quality dirt-filled cracks. Most belays are bolted. Rappel the route to descend (See the attached topo).

P1-4: Easy free climbing to a ledge.
P5: Straightforward aid with moderate levels of dirt and bushes.
P6: Wandering aid/free climbing leads up to "The Dolphin's Butt Hole". Climb though the roof with tricky moves (#2 copperheads useful), passing the only rivet on the route at a blank section. Bush grovel to the belay.
P7: Follow the cool diagonal crack, starting with beak-protected free climbing and finishing with aid.
P8-9: Awesome cracks up the headwall, mostly protected by #3 beaks and other shenanigans.
P10: "The Filthy Bush Muncher". Traverse and tension left through dirty cracks and bushes to emerge at a good crack which leads up to the belay.
P11: Mixed aid and free climbing up the cool dyke.
P12: Runout free climbing to a tree/gear belay.
P13-15: Traverse left into Gwaihir, following this route to the top of the wall.
content.location: Cross the river and hike up the main Carag-dur trail for approx 30 minutes to a junction. Take the left trail and follow it to the base of the wall, where you will see an obvious large right-facing corner system. Pitches 1-4 go up this corner.
content.protection:
25x Beaks (mostly #2 and #3)

4x Arrows

5x Heads

Hooks: 1 set

Nuts: 1 set (offsets useful)

4 each cams to #0.75

2 each cams #1 to #3

1 each cams #4 to #6

(Cam sizes are BD Camalots)

content.description:
450m tall.

The first main wall to make its presence known whene you arrive in the Eldred. Caragdur is a 400m tall ocean of immaculate slab split by one massive roof feature (The Dolphin). The left side of the wall still sports potential for some nice longish free climbs if the gardening effort were put in. The middle of the wall is impressively blank and is so heavily clad with vegetation that big sections of the wall have fallen off in recent years from tree roots behind exfoliating flakes. The far right hand side of Caragdur is one of the Eldred's only high concentrations of moderate--challenging crack climbs, therefore making it the Eldred's best option for 5.10-5.11 crack climbers.

Approach:
Drive 1 minute passed the CAD Climber's camp, park beside or near the large sandy pullout on the right. An old road leads downhill on the left for 30 seconds. Turn right to find the zipline across the Eldred River. On the other side of the river follow the well worn amazing trail uphill for roughly 20 minutes to a junction marked by a long strip of yellow flagger. The trail traverses right from here and leads passed two rock slide paths. Another 10-15 minutes uphill while contouring rightwards along the wall brings you to "Building Gondolin", the obvious shimmering right-leaning finger/tight hands crack. Total approach time from CAD Climbers Camp is around 45mins, 1 hour for slow parties.
